{"Events": [{"Event Name": "Muting of the Sepoys", "Description": "The mutiny of the sepoys in the Bengal army began in 1857, caused by the introduction of the greased cartridge for the Enfield rifles, which was believed to be greased with cow and pig fat, as part of a conspiracy theory.", "Participants/People": ["sepoys"], "Location": "India", "Place": null, "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "Rumours spread quickly that the cartridge was greased with cow and pig fat, which fitted neatly into a long circulating conspiracy theory that the colonial authorities were out to destroy the religion of all Indians and convert them into Christianity.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "Mangal Pandey's Rebellion", "Description": "On March 29, 1857, Mangal Pandey led a protest against the use of the greased cartridge by the sepoys, firing at his European officers.", "Participants/People": ["Mangal Pandey"], "Location": "Barrackpore", "Place": null, "Start Date": "1857-03-29", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "He was apprehended, court-martialed, and hanged in April. He became the first martyr patriot of the Indian mutiny, celebrated in the film Mangal Pandey: The Rising.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "The First War of Indian Independence", "Description": "The term 'First War of Indian Independence' was popularized by Veer Savarkar, who called it a 'First War of Indian Independence'.", "Participants/People": ["Veer Savarkar"], "Location": "India", "Place": null, "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "This term has been contested for its accuracy and whether it was a war of independence. The government of India officially endorsed the term 'First War of Independence' on its 150th anniversary.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "Outbreak of 1857", "Description": "The outbreak of 1857, caused by the alleged 'dishonour' of women, sparked national rage in India and London. The blood of European women and children was shed at Meerut, Delhi, and Awadh. The perceived sense of injustice easily excited emotions.", "Participants/People": ["John Premble", "Jane Robinson", "Dipesh Chakrabarty", "William Dalrymple"], "Location": "India", "Place": "Various locations", "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": "1857", "Key Details": "Alleged dishonor of women, bloodshed, national rage, perceived sense of injustice, pain and suffering of ordinary women and men, both Indian and English.", "Day": "null", "Month": "null", "Year": "null", "General Comments": "null"}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "The Mutiny of 1857", "Description": "The Mutiny of 1857 was an uprising against British rule in India in 1857. It resulted in a year of bloody warfare and left Indians suspicious in the eyes of the British.", "Participants/People": ["Indians", "British"], "Location": "India", "Place": "Across India", "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": "1858", "Key Details": "Lasting imprints on British imagination and policies towards India", "Day": "null", "Month": "null", "Year": "null", "General Comments": "General Comments: The Mutiny of 1857 had a lasting impact on British perception of Indians and shaped British policies towards India for years to come. It resulted in racial exclusivism in both Britain and India."}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "The 1857 Rebellion", "Description": "The 1857 Rebellion, also known as the First War of Independence, was a significant event in the history of Indian nationalism. It marked a shift in colonial policies towards more autocracy and a heightened sense of Indian nationalism. The rebellion was fueled by religious fervor and a desire for self-government. It became a key moment in the evolution of Indian nationhood and continues to be a source of inspiration for various strands of Indian nationalism.", "Participants/People": null, "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": "1857", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "The rebellion was primarily fueled by religious fervor and a desire for self-government.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "Recitation of names", "Description": "Recitation of names held by British side and Indian side in memory of the 250 rebels hanged and British prisoners put to death at the mouth of guns near Peshawar by the orders of Colonel John Nicholson in May 1857 and the following month in Jhansi by the rebels. The event was a commemoration of personal grief and loss.", "Participants/People": ["British side", "Indian side"], "Location": "Peshawar and Jhansi", "Place": "near Peshawar and Jhansi", "Start Date": "May 1857", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "250 rebels hanged, British prisoners put to death", "Day": "05", "Month": "05", "Year": "1857", "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "The Order Has Been Carried Out", "Description": "The Order Has Been Carried Out, a book by Alessandro Portelli, is a study of the wives and children of 335 unarmed and innocent civilians who were mercilessly gunned down by Nazi occupation forces in Rome on March 24, 1944 in retaliation for a partisan attack on some Nazi personnel the day before. It explores the expression of grief built into everyday practices, leaving no traces for the future historian.", "Participants/People": ["Alessandro Portelli"], "Location": "Rome", "Place": "Rome", "Start Date": "1944", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "Study of the wives and children of 335 unarmed and innocent civilians who were mercilessly gunned down by Nazi occupation forces in Rome on March 24, 1944", "Day": "03", "Month": "03", "Year": "1944", "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "The Rebellion of 1857", "Description": "The Rebellion of 1857 was a major uprising against British rule in India. It was sparked by a variety of factors, including discontent with the British East India Company's policies, religious tensions, and a desire for independence. The rebellion began in May 1857 and lasted for several months, involving a wide range of participants including sepoys, peasants, and even some members of the Indian elite. The British were ultimately successful in suppressing the rebellion, but its legacy continues to be felt in India today.", "Participants/People": ["Indian rebels", "British colonialists"], "Location": "India", "Place": "various", "Start Date": "May 1857", "End Date": "September 1857", "Key Details": "The rebellion began in Meerut and quickly spread to other parts of India, including Delhi, Kanpur, and Lucknow.", "Day": "01", "Month": "05", "Year": "1857", "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "British colonial debates", "Description": "The British colonial debates have already been suggested and are too obvious to need further elaboration. I will not pursue here the representation of the revolt by Hindu nationalists. But more can still be said about the Indian reactions. There were two models of modern nationhood presented to India during colonial rule. They are not usually separated, though they have been implicitly by scholars of international law, for example by James Crawford in a volume discussing the extension of the concept of rights. He advanced a thoroughly intermingled definition of the state as the social fact of a territorial community of persons with a certain political organisation.", "Participants/People": [], "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": null, "End Date": null, "Key Details": null, "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "The East India Company", "Description": "The East India Company conquered and annexed hundreds of kingdoms in India, covering 1.6 million square kilometres and including roughly three-quarters of the population. Additionally, it annexed 800,000 square kilometres and a quarter of the population, leaving approximately 500-600 nominally sovereign Indian \"princes\" who kept their thrones but struggled under British indirect rule and feared annexation. The East India Company became the largest employer of Indians through its armies, civil administration and commercial undertakings. ", "Participants/People": null, "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": "1600", "End Date": "1857", "Key Details": "The East India Company was the largest employer of Indians through its armies, civil administration and commercial undertakings.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": "General Comments: The passage outlines the historical context of Indians in Britain up to 1857, focusing on the role of the East India Company and its impact on Indian society."}]}

{"Events": [{"Event Name": "The Strangers' Home for Asiatics, Africans, and South Sea Islanders' opened", "Description": "The Strangers' Home for Asiatics, Africans, and South Sea Islanders' opened in Commercial-road, Limehouse, under its secretary and manager, lieutenant-colonel R Marsh Hughes, late of the East India Company's army. This institution's name linked various ethnicities of the working classes collectively as \"Strangers\", reflecting current British attitudes. The Home (which remained open until 1927) assumed many paternalistic functions over working-class Indians in Britain, including caring for and controlling them and arranging for their employment on the passage home.", "Participants/People": [null], "Location": "Commercial-road, Limehouse", "Place": "Limehouse", "Start Date": "1856", "End Date": null, "Key Details": "opened in Commercial-road, Limehouse, under its secretary and manager, lieutenant-colonel R Marsh Hughes, late of the East India Company's army.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": null}, {"Event Name": "Indian diplomatic and political missions to London", "Description": "During the early 19th century, as well as the late 19th century mentioned above, the increasingly numerous Indian diplomatic and political missions to London also provided centers for distinctly Indian social life there. Some 30 embassies from deposed or threatened Indian princes, or the princes themselves, had reached London by 1857. Once in Britain, the most effective among these ambassadors, including Raja Rammohun Roy who lived there during the last three years of his life (1831-33) representing Mughal emperor Muhammad Akbar II, learned about and manoeuvred through the world of British politics, often aligning with British opposition politicians in critiquing and embarrassing the British government or East India Company administration in India. Some successfully obtained enhanced pensions and influence in high British society, including with the British monarch. While no official British policies in India were reversed by the lobbying and bribing done by these Indian delegations, colonial officials apparently restrained themselves somewhat from particularly egregious annexations or other imperial assertions by the knowledge that their deeds would face hostile scrutiny in London.", "Participants/People": [null], "Location": null, "Place": null, "Start Date": null, "End Date": null, "Key Details": "During the early 19th century, as well as the late 19th century mentioned above, the increasingly numerous Indian diplomatic and political missions to London also provided centers for distinctly Indian social life there. Some 30 embassies from deposed or threatened Indian princes, or the princes themselves, had reached London by 1857. Once in Britain, the most effective among these ambassadors, including Raja Rammohun Roy who lived there during the last three years of his life (1831-33) representing Mughal emperor Muhammad Akbar II, learned about and manoeuvred through the world of British politics, often aligning with British opposition politicians in critiquing and embarrassing the British government or East India Company administration in India. Some successfully obtained enhanced pensions and influence in high British society, including with the British monarch. While no official British policies in India were reversed by the lobbying and bribing done by these Indian delegations, colonial officials apparently restrained themselves somewhat from particularly egregious annexations or other imperial assertions by the knowledge that their deeds would face hostile scrutiny in London.", "Day": null, "Month": null, "Year": null, "General Comments": "These missions provided centers for distinctly Indian social life in London."}]}
